data.body: Let's discuss the behavior of capacitors when they are connected in series. Imagine we have two capacitors, \( C_1 \) and \( C_2 \), combined in series. In this configuration, the left plate of \( C_1 \) and the right plate of \( C_2 \) are connected to the terminals of a battery and hold charges \( Q \) and \( -Q \), respectively.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Now, to maintain charge neutrality, the right plate of \( C_1 \) must have a charge of \( -Q \), and the left plate of \( C_2 \) must have a charge of \( Q \). This way, the net charge on each capacitor is zero, preventing an electric field from forming in the conductor connecting \( C_1 \) and \( C_2 \). Essentially, the charges on the two plates (\( \pm Q \)) are the same on each capacitor in the series combination.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The total potential drop \( V \) across the combination is the sum of the potential drops \( V_1 \) and \( V_2 \) across \( C_1 \) and \( C_2 \), respectively.
